channel.title: Maggie Appleton / @Mappletons
channel.description: Twitter feed for: @Mappletons. Generated by nitter.privacydev.net

item.title:
RT by @Mappletons: People often ask me what’s so special about Future of Coding London.
“The people” is one obvious answer.
“The demos” is where it’s really at.
@Mappletons and @TodePond most of all created this atmosphere where people feel free to share everything from scrappy fiddles to things that might (Bill Nye voice) change the world!
So if you’ve been working on something “mind blowing”, “pretty cool”, “kinda neat” or “look at this weird thing that happened” that you’d like to show us on Feb 28:
Please go find the demo submission form on our event page on Luma (sorry X discourages links).
We’d love to see your thing!!
item.dc:creator: @anselm_io
item.description:
People often ask me what’s so special about Future of Coding London.

“The people” is one obvious answer.

“The demos” is where it’s really at.

@Mappletons and @TodePond most of all created this atmosphere where people feel free to share everything from scrappy fiddles to things that might (Bill Nye voice) change the world!

So if you’ve been working on something “mind blowing”, “pretty cool”, “kinda neat” or “look at this weird thing that happened” that you’d like to show us on Feb 28:

Please go find the demo submission form on our event page on Luma (sorry X discourages links).

We’d love to see your thing!!

item.title:
R to @Mappletons: If you want to demo at the next event (in Feb / March), here's the signup link: https://foc-london.notion.site/174379f0e4cd8072b7c8edac4a068b57
Can be anything you like. The weirder the better.

item.title:
Pleased to announce @anselm_io and @TodePond are taking over running the London Future of Coding meetup while I'm out on mat leave this year 🎉
They've both been committed community members since the beginning and the perfect people to take over.
Join the Luma calendar for future events here: http://lu.ma/foclondon
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons

item.title:
A few months ago I started writing a short note about my experience of pregnancy so far… somehow turned into 6000+ words
I had a lot of thoughts on fruit babies, naturalness narratives, wild bananas, and the existential quality of growing someone new
http://maggieappleton.com/growing-a-human
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons

item.title:
New creation in the works. Should be fully baked by March.
Most impressive thing I’ve ever done without having any clue what I’m doing.

item.title: R to @Mappletons: Solved! Sponsorship secured. (Though if you want to sponsor future ones, do get in touch)
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons
item.description: Solved! Sponsorship secured. (Though if you want to sponsor future ones, do get in touch)

item.title: R to @Mappletons: I'm still actively looking for sponsors for this edition. If you work for a company that wants to present to a willing audience of creative developers (mix of web, backend, ML) – get in touch! Costs £400-500 and you get a 15-20min demo slot to say anything you like.
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons
item.description:
I'm still actively looking for sponsors for this edition.
If you work for a company that wants to present to a willing audience of creative developers (mix of web, backend, ML) – get in touch!
Costs £400-500 and you get a 15-20min demo slot to say anything you like.

item.title:
Just put up the next London Future of Coding meetup: https://lu.ma/6wesen56
Friday, November 22nd at @nwspk
Festive edition! 🎄 Doing a pub quiz on computing history instead of our usual demos. Come for silly games, mince pies, and obscure programming references.
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons

item.title:
R to @Mappletons: Losing a hyper-social place to put crappy, half-baked sketches and ideas, and get real reactions to them, is one of the larger losses at stake.
Idea-development space requires more than a Twitter-shaped platform. Also needs a lively culture of generous replies, yes-and-ing, and good shitposting. Waiting for that culture to develop elsewhere...
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons
item.description:
Losing a hyper-social place to put crappy, half-baked sketches and ideas, and get real reactions to them, is one of the larger losses at stake.

Idea-development space requires more than a Twitter-shaped platform. Also needs a lively culture of generous replies, yes-and-ing, and good shitposting. Waiting for that culture to develop elsewhere...

item.title:
R to @Mappletons: RSS isn't dead. Following single sites still works. But community distribution and curation feel like the missing pieces here.
Hard not to blame it all on the downfall of the Twitter algorithm. I'm trying to post on Bluesky more (http://bsky.app/profile/maggieappleton.com), but it's still quiet and lacks the raw mass of people here.
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons
item.description:
RSS isn't dead. Following single sites still works. But community distribution and curation feel like the missing pieces here.

Hard not to blame it all on the downfall of the Twitter algorithm. I'm trying to post on Bluesky more (bsky.app/profile/maggieapple…), but it's still quiet and lacks the raw mass of people here.

item.title:
R to @Mappletons: We're in a weird limbo shift without the right cultural infrastructure to encourage, support, distribute, and curate good quality personal writing and research.
If people are writing thoughtful, quality things on personal sites or gardens, I don't know how we'd ever find them.
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons
item.description:
We're in a weird limbo shift without the right cultural infrastructure to encourage, support, distribute, and curate good quality personal writing and research.

If people are writing thoughtful, quality things on personal sites or gardens, I don't know how we'd ever find them.

item.title:
Re-reading Ribbonfarm's retirement post, feeling a bit despondent about the current state of personal writing online: https://www.ribbonfarm.com/2024/10/10/ribbonfarm-is-retiring/
High quality, long-form blogs are hard to come by. Twitter is disintegrating as a distribution platform. Curators are dying out...
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons
item.description:

item.title: R to @Mappletons: Also The Grey Area is one of the best podcasts I know of. Sean Illing so good at engaging people in reasonable debate.
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons
item.description: Also The Grey Area is one of the best podcasts I know of. Sean Illing so good at engaging people in reasonable debate.

item.title: Ta-Nehisi Coates has the same energy of all my favourite professors from university; bold claims, spades of integrity, high standards. I miss being exposed to this kind of attitude on a weekly basis. Exceptionally rare and special. https://podcasts.apple.com/gb/podcast/the-gray-area-with-sean-illing/id1081584611?i=1000672997115
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons
item.description: Ta-Nehisi Coates has the same energy of all my favourite professors from university; bold claims, spades of integrity, high standards. I miss being exposed to this kind of attitude on a weekly basis. Exceptionally rare and special. podcasts.apple.com/gb/podcas…

item.title:
Consistently baffled by The Discourse on falling fertility rates and endless speculation (primarily by men) on all possible causes of it.
Certainly a many-causes-situation. But I've grown up surrounded by community and family stories of pre ~1980's women unable to access birth control, made to have children they didn't want, made to marry and become housewives & mothers despite wanting something else.
Seems fairly clear the main driver is there are fewer unwanted babies born to women who have the right to choice and agency over their own lives now. Net positive, as far as I can tell.
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons

Seems fairly clear the main driver is there are fewer unwanted babies born to women who have the right to choice and agency over their own lives now. Net positive, as far as I can tell.

item.title: R to @Mappletons: Funny how being a reader of this blog became a type of person as well. One of my current friend groups is still best described as “people who have read a lot of Ribbonfarm”
item.dc:creator: @Mappletons
item.description: Funny how being a reader of this blog became a type of person as well. One of my current friend groups is still best described as “people who have read a lot of Ribbonfarm”
